Up 2%. Don't really know where to go with this as evidence is mounting that passive genocide is a very real possibility. We've already seen forced relocation and ghettoization of the Rohingya (there, I said it); now we're up to the denial of identity, deprivation and deportation stage. There's something awfully familiar about this. Big question is whether EWP will register a mass killing if these people are simply allowed to die of preventable diseases or are left with no option but a dangerous escape.
Raising 2% as US insistence on naming the Rohingya may fan nationalistic aggression.
Updating for passage of time, lack of obvious friction between new government and military.

EPW's Expert Opinion pool is relatively high at 10%, compared to GJOpen's consensus of 5%. I'm reducing slightly from my 5% of last month because there has been no indication of brewing mass killings under the new regime, which is probably trying to bring all parties together for talks under the democratic umbrella.

Myanmar, has Muslim minorities being persecuted. The Isis and al Qaeda from next door Bangladesh will feed off this.
The newly formed government is a weakness.

God willing, no. The refugee situation in Myanmar has been catastrophic, pleasantly speaking. It's a damn shame, given the aid available so nearby.  Yet, it is in the nature of the respective government to just say, "Oh yeah, did you hear about that? Crazy, how nationalist can get so upset over SEPARATISTS?" Shame how some people are unique...just like everyone else...

Curfew has been lifted after 4 years, it seems progress has been made in Myanmar.
http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/03/29/asia-pacific/myanmar-lifts-four-year-curfew-in-state-after-communal-violence/
country presents almost no interest to outside parties
Reducing from 10% on 2nd March. The transition to semi-civilian rule has proceeded peacefully.
Because of the new Democratic government, violence will no longer be the first response.
With the new government settling in it is hard to predict, may depend on how threatened the military feel.
On a good way to become a democratic state. History wise Myanmar has a huge potential to become a powerful player in their geographic area.

What now for Myanmar? Is Aung Sun Suu Kyi becoming a 'democratic dictator'
http://www.smh.com.au/world/what-now-for-myanmar-is-aung-sun-suu-kyi-becoming-a-democratic-dictator-20160331-gnuxdo.html
Durch den demokratischen Prozess der eingesetzt hat sowie weiteren Faktoren wir oben genannter Fall nicht eintreten.
It seems like electoral politics, in some form, is taking hold in Myanmar.
After Myanmar elections with populist 'non-president' Aung Suu Kyi the State is looking far more stable as it moves to economic development, which would be severely hindered by Rohinga genocide.

There are many armed groups and a low level civil war in several regions. The army has given up (some) control, but could feel forced to step back in. The rohingya will continue to suffer, and they may become pawns in a battle between the army and the elected govt
I just cannot see it. so I go up to 5 no hedgehawg on EWP limited application  of strategy and public policy considerations.

A major concern is the friction that is emerging between ethnic groups. The fighting between TNLA and RCSS in Northern Shan State is raising the acrimony between Shan and Palaung ethnic groups. The peace dialogue will probably exacerbate the divisions between signatories and non-signatories of the National Ceasefire Agreement and between bigger and smaller ethnic groups. This could be further fueled by the release of the Census data on ethnicity and religion. The recent election of U Htin Kyaw as president shows Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's extra self-confidence and willingness to hold control over all decisions and her resistance in delegating power. The challenges ahead would require a much higher degree of inclusion in decision making that can actually be a threat. There is concern and understanding among the international community of these challenges and this might mitigate the risk, which is anyway high at 66%.

Conflict and powerful companies stoke land disputes in Myanmar's Kachin
http://www.reuters.com/article/myanmar-land-idUSL8N1622WY
Changes in land ownership and use are among key issues in Myanmar's political and economic transition, with deep resentment and protests over acquisitions for infrastructure, development or large-scale agricultural projects.Up to 70 percent of Myanmar's labour force is estimated to work in agriculture. The sector accounts for 44 percent of economic output, according to consulting firm McKinsey & Co.  All land is owned by the government but farmers are given land use or tillage rights, making land use a particularly sensitive issue for small-scale farmers who make up the majority of the country's population of 51 million. Yet these rights are neither respected on the ground in practice, nor provide protection against land grabbing, activists said.

Crowd view is correct. I had marked up originally as I believed that the delay between the election and a NLD leader being installed  as President could result in several  scenarios that are  thought in the political science literature  to increase the likelihood  of xenophobic and repressive genocide,
I am assuming that NLD has an even stronger commitment to  detecting and preventing genocide,

Not likely especially after the election in 2015. After series of bloody conflicts in past years, the public is very much aware of how such communal violence could be detrimental to their community and their aspiration for democracy and freedom.
With peaceful democratic elections, Myanmar is now becoming a more open, democratic society.
Seems like transition relatively smooth - hopeful sign.
Lowering based on the news from the capital. The risks for Kachins, Karens and the like remain significant.

Trimming to 9 percent on signs that the NLD and military will be able to cohabitate in government for a while. This lowers the risk of a state-led mass killing as part of a reactionary coup or in response to protest activity that might have occurred if the military had blocked the NLD from taking power, and I think those were the main pathways by which this event might have occurred this year.

Plus 25.
There are 200 000 Rohinggya in Bangladesh and another 200,000.00 in Thailand.
They and all the other refugees are surrounded and stateless.
No passports, birth certificates, visas. No platinum cards.
The Rohinggya diaspora is all over South China Sea and Indonesia and they the Rohinggya have no hope.
See UNHCR
The rest are surrounded in Greece Turkey Syria Iraq.
These are a significant part of of the 10,000,000 stateless people.
Based on the definition, there is a serious risk  of event.
The delay in transition of power exacerbates this.
Assume Army and Aung do not control Buddhist extremist.
I thought those words were antonyms.
Not in Burma.
Been there.
They have happened frequently already; extremist muslims are growing in number.
The year of the Fire Monkey

Political stability and general situation looks OK-ish compared to past, and economic situation is still improving, but it's fragile depending on external global economy, weather and internal tensions. Rohingya in Rakhine and MNDCAA in Kokang could be potential areas of more conflict. Though recent desire for international engagement and enrichment could counter any mass killing being too large or open.
ISIS is recruiting there so mass killings may be reversed to protect Rohingya Muslims
>What drives mass killings in underdeveloped countries, in general?
Military leaders will want to retain what public support it already has.
The political establishment's lack of commitment to equality before the law will continue to keep the violence between Buddhists and the Muslim's on the forefront.

Myanmar is in the midst of a movement toward a less authoritative government to a more open economic model. Often there is a a little chaos in a move like this,,,, Those that can't have control will create chaos. This chaos will be used to try and take control and many extremist groups will hit conditions like this as they move toward a more modern western type life.
Myanmar is trying very hard to become a civilized country, encourage tourism, foreign investment and trade. They'll do everything they can do maintain civil order.

With the transition from military rule to electoral rule (using the term because of the tentative nature of politics in Myanmar) and the election of a President within the next 10 days or so, the risk of mass killings or genocide on the part of the new government is somewhat low;  their is no record of how the new government would respond to or react to engagement by or among various rebel groups against the current direction of the country.  Since their such a large amount of uncertainty including limited open reporting of political activity in the country, it is always possible, however at present, with a low degree of such a possibility.

Newly formed, unstable democracy;
Global warming induced natural disaster (flooding) likely, causing upheaval and competition for resources. 
Military junta will feel insecure, want to reestablish power, will target democratic proponents; and/or radical Buddhist monks will target vulnerable "infidel" populations.
At risk group: Rohingya refugees.

Focus in Myanmar is on a peaceful handover to an elected civilian government (albeit "guided" by the military). Affirming my forecast from last month, and noting that EWP's expert opinion poll is also at 10% http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/106

My main concern is with something flaring up before the new government takes over -- they won't end the possibility of a mass killing, but they should lower the probability. There's a chance that more than 1000 could die anyway under the "starvation/medical deprivation" definition -- maybe they've already hit 1000 -- but I don't know if that will be easy to uncover or to count in time. Adjusting upward slightly to match my new focus on nonviolent "killings".
Buddhist monks is unpredictable this will vary on there individual principles that will push them to initiate it or it can be coming from politically motivated

BBC reported on  25 Feb. that there were clashes erupting in Northern Myanmar over opium poppy fields. With a weak economic backbone and a relatively diverse ethnic background, despite the fact that Myanmar has trying to induce democracy, it would be extremely difficult to maneuver it. Even if the regime has a strong aspiration for a solid political platform, there are higher chances of them resorting to violence against ethnic groups in the form of ethnic cleansing in order to stabilize Myanmar.
The situation is still largely unstable

With information being very scarce and with a lot of it reliant on refugee hearsay, I don't see high odds for any provable (at least in time for the deadline) deaths above the 1k additional threshold as defined on this site.  While the odds are said to be increased, it is hard to parse out the activism vs. ultimate reality here. 5% is still high odds if it were my own neighborhood, but viewed vs. higher-hazard areas like the Congo, this area doesn't seem likely to hit the definition in the next 11 months barring extreme events snowballing.

"Despite continued government restrictions, some Rohingya had not left because they were holding out hope for the new government led by Aung San Suu Kyi’s NLD, said Smith of Fortify Rights. “Many Muslims in Rakhine State tell us they hope Daw Suu will usher in a better day for them. Anything, they say, will be better than the past,” he said. (http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/news/heavy-price-to-pay-for-freedom-1988897)

As a base probability I would say that in the 5 last years there was roughly an episode of serious violence/ mass killing against Muslims every 2 years (riots in 2011, 2012 and 2014 see  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persecution_of_Muslims_in_Myanmar) so my base probability would be 50%.
But, like Ethiopia, unlikely to be reported fully.
Sadly, I expect a far greater chance of increased mass killing (by current forces and others yet to begin) than I do of civility and peace among citizens.
With the regime being secretive than before, we can state that their may be chances of mass killings being higher.

In the transition from a military run nation to the beginnings of an elected government there will be challenges to power centers.  New boundaries will need to be set delineating how much and which powers will be allowed to leave the control of the military.  Generally it is force which will set those boundaries.  The challenge will come from those who will have the most to gain and that very same group will be those to whom the military lease want to have new or additional power.   The result will conflict leading to large scale loss of life.
(no change) Interesting article, including "ethnic minorities that make up 40 percent of the population:"

It seems unlikely that after such a lengthy transition process the military will be interested in a crackdown. As the military has been the oppressive organization against other groups, it seems unlikely they would risk the transition for any grievances that might interrupt the democratization process in the near term. History of violence an unrest means that some groups might unexpectedly conduct such attacks for various grievances
The track record of this country.

increasing my forecast by 5%. A new president is coming in, and the holdover CIC has his term renewed for five years. He is already 60 yo and theoretically should be forced to retire. Given the ongoing talks with the new president this seems like a strong move, and slightly increases the risk of breakdown, in which case the CIC may cause some military troubles. The military, after all, is guaranteed political seats and is an independent political party for now.
The Buddhists of Myanmar regard themselves as the last line of defence against Islamic invaders - extremely high chance of another mass killing

Raising up a few points based on reports of 3,000 people displaced during combat between two rebel groups that I admittedly know very little about. 
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3449016/Thousands-displaced-Myanmar-rebel-clashes-UN.html
Brutal part of the world and a long 10 months.
The holding of elections in Myannmar is a positive sign. The army is in control of the country in a benign manner today.
New government will result in the people having some hope
There's a lot of tension but no mass killing in 2016
Initial forecast, primary influences:  reading sources in Khalid's Feb 3 forecast and a link that I lost suggesting less chances after an election
Myanmar moving towards democracy will help not having mass killings
Almost a year out. I am going to say low chance on this one.
With elections coming up, tempers will be high.

Rohingya are a Muslim minority in a country of oppressed minority groups used to violence and ethnic cleansing. While the NLD's new majority in office will help to curb outbreaks toward Karen and other Burmese groups this sub group may likely be at more risk to violence from more than just state groups as they are also a religious minority. Thus according to the definition on this question, it's likely that between state groups and others in a culture used to this kind of treatment of minority groups, reaching 1,000 deaths by January 1, 2017 is a real possibility. By definition on this question taking into consideration threats from state and non-state groups 1,000 deaths is not that hard to reach unfortunately.

Violence against the muslim minority has occured several times in the last 100 years, but the most recent flair up of violence led by the 969 movement in 2013 only led to the death of about 300 muslims according to the website genocide watch. Indeed the murder rate is quite high (>8000 in 2012), but much of this seems to be driven by the large drug trade and lesser based on racial cleansing. Even reports I have red by the Wirathu, the leader of 969 seem not to encourage violence predominantly, but rather seem concerned with the political issue of whether these people should be granted citizenship. The recent election of a more moderate government, with the massive defeat of the anti-islamic coalition seem to suggest that people disagree with the more extreme views of this party. Deaths at the rates exceeding the amount defined here (1000) seem to have not happened here since the 1930s, and thus it seems somewhat unlikely that it would occur in the next year, barring some unforeseen act of violence by a muslim against a buddhist (seems the 2013 case was brought about the supposed rape of a buddhist woman by 3 muslim men). Need to do more research about the rates of anti-muslim murders by similar neighboring buddhist majority countries like Thailand.
1000 is a lot.  There might be flare ups but things would have to go very awry to hit that threshold.

Suggest people read the complete definition of mass killing linked below the question. It is quite broad. In contrast with the term "episode" which to me connotes a brief period, the linked definition is 1,000 people over one year. It also is phrased such that one would count (e.g.) indirect deaths from a pogrom or forced movement from refugee camps, etc,
Cultural / religious unrest - though I do not understand the concept of militant budism.  It's an oxymoron
Given the peaceful transition of the regime and a new economic boom.

I think that actual chance is about 5% in this year, but it seems that from statistical point of view it is better to gradually lower estimates... Also before the president is elected there may be still unforeseen problems..

starting with the Early Warning Project estimate seems reasonable. But that only includes "state led" mass killing. So, increasing it by 5% for other mass killings. There doesnt seem to be a lot of news on this conflict lately so staying conservative for now.
(no change) Wish I knew how to judge how deaths related to neglect in various forms would be judged. I believe it requires more pro-active violence.
Now and 2017 is a long time.
Might be Buddhist mobs against the Rohingyas. Maybe even incited by pro-junta forces that are worried by something Aung San Suu Kyi is proposing in an effort to portray her as a Muslim-lover.
The Budist majority are trying to drive out the Muslim minority before ISIS gains a foot hold
Political leadership changes will cause opposing groups to find ways to cause disruption and blame others.
Economic hardship will continue to drive extremist activity in the Middle East and beyond for some time.
i'm going with 15% after reading Statistical Risk Assessment.

Following the consensus and the high threshold for a mass killing (1000 people in one year should be considered for civil war) makes a YES answer unlikely. As long as the government remains relatively stable (no relevant armed insurgencies and a good control of its own security forces) the likelihood remains low. In case of a threat to the government and increase would be necessary.

I'm reconsidering my earlier forecast, which effectively rejected the Early Warning Project's 2015 statistical risk assessment and focused on the base rate, and starting over. This time, I'm accepting that statistical forecast as the best current estimate of the risk of a state-led mass killing and then adding my best guess at the base-rate risk of non-state mass killing (1 percent) to it to get to 14 percent. I will adjust that number downward for passage of time and would probably move it upward in response to coup attempts, escalations of any kind of violent rebellion, the onset of a major nonviolent campaign, or evidence of violence that meets the project's criteria for mass killing.
The mass killing of more the 100 people occur very rarely without an open conflict. 1000 people almost never
Myanmar transition seem to go well, and so I see no reason for a mass killing except versus a Muslim tribe, but it would still need to kill over 1000 people.

Despite the best efforts of extremist monks, killings are on the order of ~100 people. With the new elections and a less nationalistic climate, I have trouble seeing many timelines where the violence gets worse this year.

1000 people is a lot, and leadership is changing in a way that is disadvantageous to would-be killers. I'll go a little lower than the crowd here, mostly on instinct: This just doesn't feel like it will be a "thing that happened in 2016" when we look back on this year.
Seems as though a mass killing is 1,000 deaths.  Seems unlikely - the cool season (now) is good for combat and has been relatively quiet.

Groups attacking each other seems a fairly regular occurrence in in Myanmar, including yearly anti-Muslim riot in 2012, 2013, and 2014. These incidents are usually on the order of 100 people killed but factors such are rising anti-immigrant feeling in Australia and surrounding countries, economic malaise rippling out from China,  or continuing internal political uncertainty could led to violence which passes the 1000 person threshold.
There will be communal violence but not sufficient to meet the definition.
Democracy has come too far for a mass killing to happen.

The definition of "mass killing" includes death by starvation conditions and denial of medicines among those 140,000+ Rohingya living in the IDP camps in Myanmar, am I correct? We are most likely to observe this kind of slow-motion killing, which is already going on, than the wave of state-sponsored violence that occurred in Rakhine State in 2012, and Meiktila in 2013. But we could see another wave of anti-Muslim violence, as well.
Not sure I was in the right ballpark before.   Also, just realized that 1000 casualties have to be deliberate, and of non-combatants.  That's a very serious event.
Take the history of these events in Myramar, adjust by economic pressure and dissident activity.

There have been very few murder sprees that hit the 1000 necessary to call it a "mass killing".  Myanmar is trying to open doors and world opinion will persuade the administration to defer the necessary commitment to support such an action.  Killing that many people takes social structure that the government can't muster.
Signs of power games in the transition.  Not sure how real it is yet, but moving up a little.
Transition of government and international pressure due to ongoing attacks on Rohinggya

While there will continue to be unrest and armed conflict in relatively remote parts of Myanmar, this will occur at a relatively low rate, and fall considerably short of meeting the definition of "mass killing".  The takeover of power by the NLD should also lessen the willingness of the central government of Myanmar to initiate or increase the use of armed force as a tool in existing or new ethnic or religious conflicts in the nation.
What appears to be the successful transition to the democratically elected government should make this decreasingly likely.
Lowering to be just north of consensus for now. I believe Myanmar may have been one country identified as likely to be (more) stressed with climate change.
Myanmar unfortunately is stable only by a few threads. The potential for an event is higher than either of the other two countries

With the peaceful opening of parliment this week and international pressure on the military to respect the results of the elections it seems unlikely significant violence will erupt. If the now majority NLD party moves cautiously, the likelihood decrease further.

The definition of Mass Killing is specific, deliberate killing of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less. There are reasons for the specificity and they are sound, the idea is to identify killings leading to genocidal events and other deliberate targeting activities. Because of the nature of the Myanmar violence the current threat is low. However, the ethnic minority can become a target of violence swiftly as the coals generally simmer beneath the surface. Yet, it is doubtful that it would reach the 1000 mark with the current liberalization movement underway.

Even though things are getting better in Myanmar, I think the chances of mass killing doesn't necessarily decrease.  Any time you have wrenching social change, and ethnic tensions, it seems the ingredients are there for a tragedy.  But looking at the expert pool 27%, and reading the explanation, I think they overadjusted.  So I'm going to start slightly below them.
Myanmar's conflict with the Karen is chronic, rather than acute. Total casualties since 2011 are apparently less than 300, although tens of thousands have been displaced.
The bar for a mass-killing is set way too high. In two or three years perhaps, but at 100 killings a month it'd take Paris+ or Krillnacht scale mass-killings each month to hit the Jan-1-2017 target.
A thousand is a lot, even in a country with divisions that run as deep as Myanmar.
I stress any group of people killed is a mass killing not just focus on 1000 or better.

My impression from a visit to Myanmar nearly ten years ago was that it was a country with enormous potential if only the military repression didn't exist. Since then the country has opened up significantly, but there have been mass killings of Rohingya in the last year or so, while there are several conflicts between the army and various ethnic groups in remote parts of the country. The (hopefully) outgoing military regime has signed peace treaties with most of the ethnic groups, and a democratic government is likely to be more inclusive. The Rohingya problem remains, however, and Aung San Suu Kyi has been notably silent about them, though they expect her to be more helpful to them in power.

I'm certainly not an expert (http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools/106), but I think starting low on this IFP is best. From the 'more info,' it's pretty clear that EWP wants to now about 'new episodes.' Meaning, "Karen" won't resolve this IFP. However, something involving the Rohingya would. Maybe I'm conflating in the wrong way, but the other IFP that's asking about Myanmar (re: government) leads me to believe that there might be some hope (?) for a reduction in violence within Myanmar. However, as the 'definitions' page makes clear, a mass killing perpetrated by a non-state actor would resolve the IFP.
I selected 75, but wrong country. Resubmitting as 50%
Initial forecast. It seems like late last year the Rohinga issue even made it to mainstream US news. Not a good sign of imminent peace.

Just a loose guess at this point, based on some reading about the current affairs of the Karen and Rohinga. Need to do more reading on the significance of Aung San Suu Kyi's historic involvement in the parliament this time around. Things look messy enough to push me a bit over into the yes territory. I'm curious how much the appointment of a new president will affect things in March.

I can't find any damn information about the number of Muslims killed in Burma in 2015. There's heaps about the number of refugees, or the number displaced, but practically nothing credible about the total number *killed* in that specific year. The most useful information I can find is a Jan 2015 LA Times article, which says that 240 Muslims have been killed in Myanmar over the last 2 years. (http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jul/15/husain-counting-violent-muslim-deaths-country-2014/?page=all).
It is possible to feel ambivalent about right on a mass murder question. These are among the most difficult for which to separate one's hopes from one's expectations.
coming back with reasons later. very happy about this question/challenge. woop!
